The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes per diem payments for care of dependents of homeless veterans and establishes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and veterans at risk of homelessness, ensuring equitable distribution across the United States, including rural communities and tribal lands. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes legal services for homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness, including housing, family law, income support, and criminal defense assistance. The Secretary may require entities in partnerships to submit periodic reports on legal services provided to homeless veterans. The Secretary may require entities in partnerships to submit periodic reports on legal services provided. The "Homeless Veterans Prevention Act of 2017" authorizes partnerships with public and private entities to provide legal services to homeless veterans and those at risk of homelessness. Additionally, the Department of Veterans Affairs is expanding its authority to provide dental care to homeless veterans. Subsection (b) of section 2062 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to extend eligibility for certain benefits to veterans enrolled for care and receiving assistance or care in specified settings for a consecutive 60-day period. The Secretary may provide funds for a grant and per diem provider in specified settings for veterans receiving assistance or care for a consecutive 60-day period, with breaks disregarded if not the veteran's responsibility. SEC. 5. Repeal of sunset on authority for referral and counseling services for veterans at risk of homelessness transitioning from certain institutions. Amends Section 2023 of title 38, United States Code by removing subsection (d) and redesignating subsection (e) as subsection (d).

SEC. 6. Extension of authority for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. Amends section 2044(e) of title 38, United States Code by adjusting funding for fiscal year 2017 to $500,000,000 and extends training entities for provision of supportive services through 2017.

SEC. 7. Requirement for Comptroller General to study Department of Veterans Affairs homeless veterans programs. SEC. 7. The Comptroller General of the United States will study Department of Veterans Affairs programs assisting homeless veterans within 270 days of this Act. The study will assess program effectiveness and review efforts to improve privacy, safety, and security for female veterans.
